cluster.cluster_name: Understand phonemes, graphemes and their correspondence
cluster.rationale: Phoneme, grapheme and GPC are the conceptual bedrock of systematic phonics; all three are mutually co-taught (C002 lists C001 and C003), and none is meaningful without the others.
cluster.inspired_by: CC ELA RF.1.2 - Phonological Awareness; RF.1.3 - Phonics and Word Recognition

concepts.description: The smallest unit of sound in spoken language (e.g., /c/ /a/ /t/)
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach phonemes through a systematic synthetic phonics programme (e.g., Letters and Sounds, Read Write Inc.). Begin with single-letter phonemes (/s/, /a/, /t/, /p/) before progressing to digraphs and trigraphs. Use oral segmenting games — say a word slowly and ask children to count the sounds on their fingers. Ensure children understand that a phoneme is a sound, not a letter, by demonstrating words where one sound is represented by more than one letter.
concepts.key_vocabulary: phoneme, sound, letter, mouth, listen, say, hear, word
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children often confuse phonemes with letters, believing that each letter always makes one sound. They may count letters rather than sounds when segmenting (e.g., thinking 'ship' has four sounds instead of three). Some children add a schwa sound to consonant phonemes (e.g., saying 'buh' instead of /b/).

concepts.description: A letter or group of letters representing a phoneme (e.g., 'sh', 'ch', 'igh')
concepts.teaching_guidance: Introduce graphemes alongside phonemes from the start of systematic phonics teaching. Use flashcards showing the grapheme with a picture cue (e.g., 'sh' with a picture of a ship). Teach children that a grapheme can be one letter (s), two letters (sh, ch, th), or three letters (igh, ear). Practise matching graphemes to phonemes using phoneme frames and magnetic letters. Display grapheme charts in the classroom for reference.
concepts.key_vocabulary: grapheme, letter, digraph, trigraph, sound, write, spell, read
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may think that every letter is a separate grapheme, leading them to split digraphs incorrectly when reading (e.g., reading 'sh' as /s/ /h/). They may struggle to understand that the same phoneme can be represented by different graphemes (e.g., /ee/ can be 'ee', 'ea', 'e-e').

concepts.description: The relationship between letters and the sounds they represent
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach GPCs in a systematic order following the school's chosen phonics programme. Start with one-to-one correspondences (one letter, one sound) before introducing alternatives. Use a 'speed sounds' routine where children see the grapheme and say the phoneme rapidly. Revisit GPCs daily through flashcard practice. When children encounter a new GPC in reading, explicitly name it and add it to the class phonics display.
concepts.key_vocabulary: grapheme-phoneme correspondence, sound, letter, match, phonics, code, alphabetic code
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children often assume each letter makes only one sound and become confused when they encounter alternative pronunciations (e.g., 'c' in cat vs city). They may not realise that English has more phonemes (approximately 44) than letters (26), requiring some sounds to be represented by letter combinations.

domain.domain_description: Phonics, decoding, word recognition and fluency development
domain.curriculum_context: Reading — word reading at KS1 focuses on teaching children the alphabetic code systematically through phonics, enabling them to decode unfamiliar words independently. Children learn the correspondences between sounds (phonemes) and letters or groups of letters (graphemes), applying this knowledge to blend sounds in order to read words and segment words for spelling. The statutory curriculum requires that by the end of Year 1, children pass the statutory Phonics Screening Check, demonstrating secure knowledge of the common grapheme-phoneme correspondences. In Year 2, pupils consolidate their phonic knowledge and develop fluency in reading high-frequency words and common exception words. The goal of word reading is automaticity — reading words accurately without conscious effort — which frees pupils' cognitive resources for comprehension.
domain.subject: English

domain_clusters.cluster_name: Understand phonemes, graphemes and their correspondence
Blend and segment sounds to decode and spell words
Recognise vowel and consonant digraphs and split digraphs
Read common exception words fluently and with expression
Assessment: Automatic word recognition, Common exception words, Reading fluency
Consolidation: Vowel digraphs, Consonant digraphs, Split digraph (+1)

content_guideline.reading_level_description: Most children are in phonics stages 2–5. Cannot decode independently. All content must be supported by audio.
content_guideline.agent_content_prompt: Do not display text to child without audio. All questions must be spoken aloud. Use only objects the child knows from everyday life (animals, food, toys, family). Maximum one concept per screen. Avoid negatives ('which is NOT...') — rephrase as positives.

pedagogy_profile.agent_pedagogy_prompt: Always start with a fully narrated worked example showing the complete answer. Then immediately practise with the same type of problem. No challenge problems before instruction — Y1 children need success to build confidence. Keep each concept isolated; do not mix topics within a session. End every session positively.

feedback_profile.feedback_example_correct: The frog jumped exactly four spaces — you counted perfectly!
feedback_profile.feedback_example_incorrect: Oh, let us count again together! [animation demonstrates]
feedback_profile.avoid_phrases: ["Wrong", "Incorrect", "That is not right", "Try again", "Well done", "Good boy/girl"]
feedback_profile.agent_feedback_prompt: Describe what the child did specifically, not how they performed. Avoid evaluative praise ('Well done!'). Use informational celebration ('You matched all five pictures!'). On error: never say wrong — redirect: 'Let us look again together.' Post-error correction is visual/animated only. No points, badges, or progress bars of any kind.

interaction_types.name: Voice Input
interaction_types.agent_prompt: Use single voiced questions only. Do not display the question text — speak it. Provide visual microphone affordance. Confirm transcription back before evaluating. Accept phonetic approximations for subject vocabulary.
interaction_types.ui_notes: Large microphone button with waveform animation. Playback button so child can hear their answer before submitting. Auto-submit after 2 seconds of silence option.

interaction_types.name: Drag and Drop — Place on Target
interaction_types.agent_prompt: Use when placement reveals understanding (e.g., ordering on number line, sorting into Venn diagram). Items should be clearly distinguishable by colour/shape. Limit to 6 draggable items maximum per screen for Y1-Y3.
interaction_types.ui_notes: Large drag handles (min 48×48px touch target). Clear snap-to-target zones. Undo button always visible. Accessibility: keyboard-navigable alternative.

interaction_types.name: Number Line — Drag Marker
interaction_types.agent_prompt: Specify the number range and expected precision (integer, 0.5, 0.1, fraction). For fractions, display both the fractional position and decimal equivalent below the line. Use after teaching formal notation to reinforce conceptual placement.
interaction_types.ui_notes: Labelled endpoints, optional intermediate markers. Snap-to-integer or snap-to-fraction-denominator mode. Shows value tooltip as user drags. Landscape orientation preferred.

interaction_types.name: Multiple Choice — 2 Options
interaction_types.agent_prompt: Offer exactly 2 options. Both should be meaningfully plausible — avoid obvious distractors. Use images rather than text where possible. Frame as a binary distinction (odd/even, living/non-living, more/less than).
interaction_types.ui_notes: Two large full-width buttons. Options can be images, icons, or large text (min 24pt). No radio buttons — full-area tap targets.

interaction_types.name: Letter Toggler (Tap to Cycle)
interaction_types.agent_prompt: Use for letter recognition and case discrimination tasks only. Present a row of tiles and ask child to tap to match a target pattern: 'Make the letters in a name show their capital form.' Do not use for phoneme discrimination — use phoneme_splitter for that. Do not use for word-building — use sentence_assembly for that. Most appropriate for Y1 letter knowledge and Y2 capitalization rules. Keep tasks concrete: 'Find the letter that starts your name.'
interaction_types.ui_notes: Large square tiles (min 60x60px). Tap to cycle: empty → lowercase → uppercase → blank (delete). Visual animation on state change. Reads the letter name aloud on each tap. Screen-reader accessible. Arrange in a row for pattern tasks. Maximum 6 tiles visible at once for Y1.

interaction_types.name: Phoneme Splitter
interaction_types.agent_prompt: Display the target word as phoneme-block tiles. Ask child to drag them apart: 'Can you split this word into its sounds?' Tap each block in sequence to hear the phoneme chain, then drag together and tap to hear the blend. Build from known phonemes: start with the vowel identification task. Use after initial sound exposure, not as first contact with a phoneme. Do not split digraphs (sh, ch, th) — keep them as single tiles.
interaction_types.ui_notes: Word displayed as coloured draggable blocks — one block per phoneme. Blocks can be dragged apart to separate or pushed together to blend. Tap a block to hear the phoneme. Blended block plays the full word. Separate phoneme tile bank for word-building tasks. Tile colour-coded by phoneme position (initial/medial/final).

interaction_types.name: Voice Recorder — Record and Playback
interaction_types.agent_prompt: Use for scientific observation recording ('Press the button and tell me what you notice'), hypothesis formation ('Say what you think will happen'), and oral explanation tasks where written production is a barrier. After recording, display the transcription and ask child to confirm: 'Is that what you meant to say?' Prefer voice_recorder over typed answers for Y1-Y3 science, geography, and history observation tasks. Do not require written follow-up unless writing is the assessed skill.
interaction_types.ui_notes: Large microphone button with pulsing animation. Live waveform display during recording. Plays back with waveform and transcribed text below. Re-record button always visible. Transcript displayed alongside audio for child to follow. Auto-punctuation in transcript. Option to submit voice or edit transcribed text.

interaction_types.name: Multiple Choice — 3 Options
interaction_types.agent_prompt: Provide 1 correct answer and 2 plausible distractors. Distractors should represent common misconceptions, not random wrong answers. Label A/B/C only if children are Y3+.
interaction_types.ui_notes: Three clearly spaced buttons. Illustrations optional from Y3 onwards. Options stacked vertically on mobile.
